abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Transport Project for
            Albania were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the
            risk to development outcome was moderate, the Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and the Borrower performance
            was moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            the expected levels of service and the penalty system should
            be defined in Output and Performance-based Maintenance
            Contract (OPBM) contracts with due consideration of the
            current condition of assets. It is important to have
            accurate asset inventory and condition data, because they
            provide the baseline for measurement of performance by the
            contractor. Monthly penalties should be defined in
            accordance with the level of service to be expected during
            the early life of the project. A sub-contracting provision
            needs to be clearly defined in the contract. The ambiguity
            regarding the extent of sub-contracting allowed under the
            contract for the Milot-Rreshen road section allowed the
            winning contractor to sub-contract all the civil works, and
            eventually act as a contract manager. In such a major
            contract, this could have led to a disastrous situation if
            not for the experience and ability of the supervision
            consultants and the contractor's staff. The contract
            should also include a clearly-defined provision about the
            main contractor's responsibility to provide its own
            major equipment (e.g., crushing plant, concrete plant and
            asphalt plant) in order to avoid forcing sub-contractors to
            rely on local suppliers.

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            Transport Project for Albania is to reduce user costs on the
            Milot - Rreshen section of the Durres - Milot - Morine
            corridor and improve access for the hinterland population,
            to introduce innovation in road maintenance on a pilot
            basis, and to contribute to the development of the
            institutional framework and implementation of road safety
            activities throughout Albania. The change, requested by the
            Government of the Republic of Albania in a letter signed by
            the Minister of Finance, dated May 31, 2010, is a
            reallocation of funds across the following categories in the
            financing agreement: i) category of consultancy to be
            increased by SDR 280,000; and ii) category of goods one to
            be reduced by SDR 280, 000. The requested reallocation is
            required to pay for an extension to the road safety
            technical assistance to allow the consultant to achieve the
            following: i) to support the actual implementation of the
            national road safety strategy and action plan, both
            developed earlier under the project; ii) to prepare a plan
            for the immediate establishment of the Secretariat under the
            Inter-ministerial Road safety Council and support the
            implementation of the plan; and iii) to identify a priority
            list of accident blacks-pots on the road network and prepare
            the detailed designs for interventions to address the
            identified blacks-pots. The funds are available for
            reallocation as certain goods and consulting services in the
            original procurement plan are not now needed, or have been
            procured from other sources. The items that will not now be
            procured through the project are traffic
            counters/classifiers, the vehicles for the project
            implementation team, and the road condition measuring equipment.

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            Transport Project for Albania is to reduce user costs on the
            Milot - Rreshen section of the Durres - Milot - Morine
            corridor and improve access for the hinterland population,
            to introduce innovation in road maintenance on a pilot
            basis, and to contribute to the development of the
            institutional framework and implementation of road safety
            activities throughout Albania. The changes, requested by the
            Government of the Republic of Albania in a letter signed by
            the Minister of Finance, dated January 21, 2010, are a
            reallocation of funds across categories in the financing
            agreement: i) category of accumulated operating costs to be
            increased by 230,000 SDR, and ii) category of consultancy
            one and two to be increased by 40,000 SDR. The requested
            reallocation is required as the delay in the reform of the
            General Roads Directorate (GRD) has resulted in a need to
            continue to pay the salaries and administrative costs of the
            project implementation team in GRD for a further period of
            twelve months. The funds are available for reallocation as
            certain goods and services in the original procurement plan
            are not now needed, or have been procured from other
            sources. The items that will not now be procured through the
            project are the breathalyzers and speed guns for the traffic
            police, and the sector specific fiduciary assessment.
